variant.bodyText: Published Quarterly by the Association for Computational Linguistics
The American Journal of Computational Linguistics (ISSN 0362-613X) is published quarterly by the Associ- ation for Computational Linguistics.

variant.bodyText: IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center Submissions of all types of material should be made to the Editor at the address given above. Additional infor- mation concerning submissions is given on the inside back cover. Copyright Â© 1980 by the Association for Computational Linguistics. The code and copyright notice appearing at the bottom of the first page of an article in this journal indicate the copyright owner's consent that copies of the article may be made for personal or internal use, or for the personal or internal use of specific clients. This consent is given on condition that the copier pay for copying beyond that permitted by Sections 107 and 108 of the U.S. Copyright Law. The per-copy fee for each article appears after the dollar sign and is to be paid through the Copyright Clearance Center, Inc. This con- sent does not apply to other kinds of copying, such as copying for general distribution, for advertising and pro- motional purposes, for creating new collective works, and for resale. Such permission requests and other permission inquiries should be addressed to the Manag- ing Editor at the address given above.
The Association for Computational Linguistics is an international professional society with membership open to any person or institution whose professional goals relate to computational linguistics.

variant.bodyText: Affiliations: The ACL is a constituent member of the American Federation of Information Processing Socie- ties, and is also associated with the International Com- mittee on Computational Linguistics. Subscriptions to the AJCL are available only through membership in the ACL. Each subscription includes both hard-copy and microfiche versions of the Journal. Annual membership dues are $15 for individuals and $30 for institutions. Joint memberships for couples are available for $20, but provide only one subscription. Postage: The AJCL is normally mailed bulk-rate. First class mailing is available in North America for an addi- tional annual charge of $6. Air-printed mailing is availa- ble overseas for an additional annual charge of $12. Back issues of the AJCL for the years 1974-1978 are available on microfiche only. The rates per annual vol- ume are $15 for individuals and $30 for institutions. First class mailing of back issues is available in North America for an additional charge of $3 per volume. Air- printed mailing of back issues is available overseas for an additional charge of $6 per volume. There were no issues in 1979. Payments for dues or back issues should be sent to the ACL Secretary-Treasurer at the address given above. Checks should be made out to the Association for Com- putational Linguistics (or to ACL) and should be payable in U.S. dollars. There is an additional $1 charge for bank processing costs for checks that are not drawn on U.S. banks. Address changes should be sent to the ACL Secretary-Treasurer at the address given above. A Note from the Editor: This issue of the American Journal of Computational Lin- guistics (AJCL) is a combined issue for the third and fourth quarters of 1980. It is Number 3-4, dated July-December. This issue contains 94 pages, which is almost double the 50 pages per quarterly issue stated in my original proposal for producing this hard-copy Journal. [Details may be found in the news article on page 49 of the January-March 1980 issue of AJCL and in the proposal reproduced on page 68 in the Microfiche Supplement of that issue.] The first two quarterly issues of 1980 consisted of 62 and 64 hard-copy pages, respec- tively. These three issues together, then, provide a total of 220 hard-copy pages for the year (plus 9 pages of Microfiche Supplement). Included in these issues are nine rather long technical articles (130 pages), ten book reviews (16 pages), 133 abstracts (34 pages), a complete membership list (18 pages), and announcements, minutes and programs of meet- ings, etc. (22 pages). In July, Michael McCord of the University of Kentucky became Associate Editor, and in October, Andrea McKenzie of IBM Research became Editorial Assistant. Both of these people contributed substantially to the publication of this issue. In 1981 we intend to publish four smaller issues on a more nearly regular schedule. We currently have about 25 articles being refereed, about 25 books to be reviewed, and a backlog of about 25 abstracts to publish. But, we would like to have still more. We continue to welcome submissions of technical articles and other material (especially abstracts of technical reports and announcements of meetings) according to the guidelines given on the inside back cover.
